gloss: (botany) a plant having a life cycle that normally takes two seasons from germination to death to complete; flowering biennials usually bloom and fruit in the second season / (of e.g. fruits and anthers) opening spontaneously at maturity to release seeds / a plant adapted to arid conditions and characterized by fleshy water-storing tissues that act as water reservoirs / a private secondary school / a religious orientation of doubt; a denial of ultimate knowledge of the existence of God / a secondary school (usually private) / a small body that contains the female germ cell of a plant; develops into a seed after fertilization / an edible white agaric that fruits in dense clusters; the gills are narrow and crowded and the stalk is fleshy and unpolished / an educational institution / an indehiscent fruit derived from a single ovary having one or many seeds within a fleshy wall or pericarp: e.g. grape; tomato; cranberry / any of various fleshy fungi of the subdivision Basidiomycota consisting of a cap at the end of a stem arising from an underground mycelium / minimal meaningful language unit; it cannot be divided into smaller meaningful units / plants grown for their large bright yellow to red flowers / special cell constituting the base of the basidium in various fungi especially of the order Tremellales / the Greek language prior to the Roman Empire / the doctrine or belief that there is no God / the form of theological rationalism that believes in God on the basis of reason without reference to revelation

(botany) a plant having a life cycle that normally takes two seasons from germination to death to complete; flowering biennials usually bloom and fruit in the second season / a day-flowering biennial or perennial of the genus Oenothera / hairy upright herb native to southeastern Asia but widely cultivated for its large glossy edible fruit commonly used as a vegetable
